community.title: Community
community.description: Connect with other cat owners, follow their journeys, share tips, and celebrate your cats' milestones together.

catFitness.overweightNotes: For overweight cats (BCS 7), use shorter, more frequent sessions to reduce joint stress. Prioritize low-impact activities. Always consult a veterinarian before starting a weight-loss exercise program.
catFitness.obeseNotes: For obese cats (BCS 8–9), use very short micro-sessions (3–5 min) with mandatory rest breaks. Low intensity only. Gradual ramp: increase by 10–20% per week if tolerated. Consult a veterinarian before starting.
catFitness.seniorMobilityNotes: For seniors with mobility limitations, focus on ground-level play. Puzzle feeders and slow-moving toys on the floor are ideal.
catFitness.activityDescLaser: Laser pointer — intense sprinting and chasing
catFitness.activityDescOutdoor: Outdoor exploration — walking, stalking, varied terrain
catFitness.activityDescFreeRoam: Free roam / self-directed play — intermittent activity
catFitness.intensityLowDesc: Gentle, ground-level play with slow-moving toys. Ideal for seniors, obese cats, cats with mobility issues, or warm-up/cool-down.
catFitness.intensityModerateDesc: Active play with moderate bursts of running, pouncing, and batting. Good for most adult cats. Not suitable for obese cats without veterinary approval.
catFitness.intensityHighDesc: Vigorous play with sprinting, jumping, and intense chase sequences. Best for young, healthy cats at normal weight with high energy.
catFitness.cooldownNotes: End each session by gradually slowing toy movement over 1–2 minutes. Let the cat make a final "kill" (catch the toy). This prevents frustration and allows heart rate to normalize.
catFitness.huntEatGroomSleep: Follow the natural feline cycle: HUNT (play session simulating predatory sequence) → EAT (offer a small meal or treat immediately after) → GROOM (cat will naturally groom) → SLEEP (cat will rest). This sequence produces the most satisfying and behaviorally complete play experience. Schedule play sessions before mealtimes when possible.
catFitness.disclaimer: All calorie estimates are approximate and based on standard veterinary energy equations (RER/MER) with conservative intensity multipliers. There is not strong direct published data for "kcal/min of cat play." Actual energy expenditure varies significantly based on individual metabolism, ambient temperature, play intensity, health status, and other factors. These figures are for general guidance only and should not replace veterinary advice. Consult a veterinarian for any weight-management program or if your cat shows signs of illness, injury, or distress during play. This app does not provide veterinary diagnosis.
catFitness.stopRulePanting: Open-mouth breathing or panting (cats should NOT pant like dogs — this indicates overexertion or respiratory distress). STOP immediately. Seek vet care if it persists beyond 2–3 minutes of rest.
catFitness.stopRuleCollapse: Collapse, inability to stand, or extreme lethargy — veterinary emergency.
catFitness.stopRuleCyanosis: Blue, purple, or pale/white gums (cyanosis) — veterinary emergency.
catFitness.stopRuleCoughing: Coughing, gagging, or wheezing during play.
catFitness.stopRuleVomiting: Vomiting during or immediately after play.
catFitness.stopRuleLimping: Limping, favoring a limb, or crying out in pain.
catFitness.stopRuleAggression: Aggression escalation (hissing, growling, flattened ears with stiff body) — cat is overstimulated.
catFitness.stopRuleHiding: Hiding or attempting to escape the play area — respect the cat's choice.
catFitness.stopRuleRefusing: Refusing to engage after being enticed — never force play.
catFitness.obeseStopRule: OBESE CAT: Stop after each 3–5 minute micro-session even if the cat seems willing to continue. Mandatory rest break of at least 10 minutes. Resume only if breathing is normal and relaxed.
catFitness.progressWeek1Obese: Start very gently. 2–3 minute micro-sessions only. Low intensity. Stop immediately if any panting or heavy breathing occurs. Mandatory 10+ minute rest between sessions.
catFitness.progressWeek1Overweight: Start gentle. Focus on engagement over exertion. Stop if panting. Rest 5+ minutes between sessions.
catFitness.progressWeek1Normal: Introduce short play sessions. Focus on building a routine.
catFitness.progressWeekFinal: Full target duration. Cat should be comfortable with this level. Continue to monitor for fatigue.
catFitness.progressWeekMid: Gradually increase session length by {{pct}} from previous week. Monitor for fatigue.
catFitness.energyProgressWeek1Obese: Start very gently. Focus on engagement, not exertion. Low intensity only. Stop immediately if any panting or heavy breathing occurs.
catFitness.energyProgressWeek1Overweight: Start gentle. Short sessions at low-to-moderate intensity. Monitor breathing throughout.
catFitness.energyProgressWeek1Normal: Introduce short play sessions. Focus on building a consistent routine.
catFitness.energyProgressWeekFinal: Full target duration reached. Maintain this level. Continue to monitor for signs of fatigue.
catFitness.energyProgressWeekMid: Gradually increase session length by {{pct}} from previous week. Monitor for fatigue and adjust accordingly.
catFitness.emergencyStopPanting: Open-mouth breathing or panting that persists after play stops — cats should NOT pant like dogs; persistent panting indicates overexertion or respiratory distress. STOP immediately and monitor. Seek veterinary care if it continues beyond 2–3 minutes of rest. (AAHA, PDSA)
catFitness.emergencyStopCollapse: Collapse or inability to stand — stop all activity immediately and seek emergency veterinary care.
catFitness.emergencyStopCyanosis: Blue, purple, or pale/white gums (cyanosis) — indicates severe oxygen deprivation. This is a veterinary emergency.
catFitness.emergencyStopLethargy: Severe lethargy or unresponsiveness during or after play — stop immediately and contact your veterinarian.
catFitness.emergencyStopCoughing: Coughing, gagging, or wheezing — may indicate respiratory distress, asthma exacerbation, or airway obstruction. Stop play and consult your vet.
catFitness.emergencyStopVomiting: Vomiting during or immediately after play.
catFitness.emergencyStopLimping: Limping, favoring a limb, or crying out in pain — stop and assess for injury.
catFitness.emergencyStopAggression: Aggression escalation (hissing, growling, flattened ears, stiff body with dilated pupils) — cat is overstimulated. End session calmly.
catFitness.emergencyStopHiding: Hiding or actively fleeing the play area — respect the cat's choice to stop.
catFitness.safetyObeseWarning1: This cat is classified as obese (BCS 8–9). Obesity places extra strain on the heart, lungs, and joints. Play sessions must be short, low-intensity micro-sessions with mandatory rest breaks. Consult your veterinarian before starting any exercise program.
catFitness.safetyObeseWarning2: Obese cats are at increased risk of respiratory distress during exertion. Watch closely for open-mouth breathing, panting, or reluctance to continue. Stop immediately if any of these occur.
catFitness.safetyOverweightWarning: This cat is classified as overweight (BCS 7). Sessions should be shorter and more frequent with moderate intensity. Gradual ramps are important — do not push for rapid increases in duration or intensity.
catFitness.safetyCardiacWarning: KNOWN CARDIAC OR RESPIRATORY DISEASE: Only very gentle, supervised play is appropriate. Stop at the first sign of labored breathing, coughing, or fatigue. Your veterinarian should approve any exercise program.
catFitness.safetyHotWarning: Hot ambient temperature detected. Cats dissipate heat poorly. Reduce session length and intensity. Ensure fresh water is available. Stop play if any panting occurs.
catFitness.safetyMobilityWarning: Mobility limitations present. Only low-impact, ground-level activities recommended. Avoid jumping or climbing.
catFitness.safetySeniorWarning: Senior cat: monitor closely for signs of pain or fatigue. Seniors may need longer warm-up periods and gentler activities.
catFitness.safetyGeriatricWarning: Geriatric cat (15+ years): increased veterinary monitoring recommended. Very gentle play only.
catFitness.restSuggestionObese: After each micro-session (3–5 min), allow a full rest period of at least 10 minutes. If the cat shows any signs of heavy breathing, extend rest to 30 minutes or more. Increase session duration by only 10–20% per week if the cat tolerates it without distress.
catFitness.restSuggestionOverweight: Rest for at least 5 minutes between sessions. Increase duration by 10–20% per week if tolerated. If the cat is not yet used to regular play, start at the lower end and progress gradually over 3–4 weeks.
catFitness.restSuggestionCardiac: This cat has known cardiac or respiratory disease. Only very gentle, low-intensity activity is recommended. Rest for at least 15 minutes between sessions. Consult your veterinarian for a specific exercise plan.
catFitness.intensityCappedWarning: Intensity was capped to "{{cap}}" based on this cat's health profile.
catFitness.durationExceededWarning: Requested duration ({{duration}} min) exceeds the recommended maximum continuous play of {{min}}–{{max}} min for this cat. Break the session into shorter segments with rest periods of at least {{breakMinutes}} minutes between them.
catFitness.obeseTimerWarning: Obese cat — max {{min}}–{{max}} min per session. Timer will auto-pause at {{max}} min.
catFitness.overweightTimerWarning: Overweight cat — max {{min}}–{{max}} min per session. Timer will auto-pause at {{max}} min.
catFitness.warningObese1: This cat is classified as obese (BCS 8–9). Obesity places significant strain on the heart, lungs, and joints. Play sessions have been limited to short, low-intensity micro-sessions with mandatory rest breaks. Consult your veterinarian before starting any exercise program.
catFitness.warningObese2: IMPORTANT: Obese cats are at increased risk of respiratory distress during exertion. Stop immediately if open-mouth breathing, panting, or reluctance to continue is observed. Allow at least 10 minutes of rest between sessions.
catFitness.warningOverweight: This cat appears to be overweight (BCS 7). The play plan has been adjusted with shorter, more frequent sessions and capped intensity. Consult your veterinarian before starting a weight-loss exercise program.
catFitness.warningUnknownWeight: This cat's weight ({{weight}} kg) may indicate overweight status depending on breed and frame. A Body Condition Score (BCS) assessment by your veterinarian is recommended for accurate classification.
catFitness.warningUnderweight: This cat may be underweight. Ensure adequate caloric intake before increasing exercise. Consult your veterinarian.
catFitness.warningCardiac: KNOWN CARDIAC OR RESPIRATORY DISEASE: Only very gentle, supervised play is appropriate. Stop at the first sign of labored breathing, coughing, or fatigue. Your veterinarian should approve any exercise program.
catFitness.warningMobility: Mobility limitations detected. Plan adjusted to low-impact activities only. Avoid jumping and climbing activities.
catFitness.warningAnxious: Anxious cat profile. Sessions are kept shorter to prevent overstimulation. Avoid laser pointers and unpredictable automated toys.
catFitness.warningHot: Hot ambient temperature: cats dissipate heat poorly. Session lengths have been reduced. Ensure fresh water is available. Stop play if any panting occurs.
catFitness.warningGeriatric: This is a geriatric cat (15+ years). Increased veterinary monitoring recommended. Watch closely for signs of pain or fatigue during play.
catFitness.toyWandSession: Start slow (mimicking prey hiding) → build to active chase (2–3 min) → let cat "catch" prey → repeat 3–4 cycles → end with a catch and treat.
catFitness.toyWandSafety1: Never leave string/feather toys unattended — ingestion risk.
catFitness.toyWandSafety3: Let cat "win" regularly to prevent frustration.
catFitness.toyLaserSession: Short bursts only (3–5 min). Move dot along floor in prey-like patterns. MUST end by leading dot to a physical toy or treat that cat can "catch".
catFitness.toyLaserSafety1: ALWAYS end with a physical catch (treat or toy) — failure causes frustration and obsessive behavior.
catFitness.toyLaserSafety4: Not recommended for anxious cats or cats prone to compulsive behaviors.
catFitness.toyBallSession: Roll ball to initiate. Let cat bat and chase. Works well for solo play between interactive sessions.
catFitness.toyBallSafety1: Choose balls too large to swallow.
catFitness.toyBallSafety2: Avoid balls with small detachable parts.
catFitness.toyKickerSession: Present toy → cat grabs with front paws and bunny-kicks. Great for core engagement. 5–10 min sessions.
catFitness.toyKickerSafety1: Check seams regularly for loose filling.
catFitness.toyCrinkleSession: Toss or hide crinkle toys to encourage investigation and batting.
catFitness.toyCrinkleSafety1: Ensure no small pieces can be chewed off and swallowed.
catFitness.toyPuzzleSession: Fill with portion of daily kibble. Start with easiest difficulty, increase gradually. 10–20 min engagement. Ideal for weight management.
catFitness.toyPuzzleSafety1: Count dispensed food as part of daily caloric intake.
catFitness.toyPuzzleSafety3: Start with easy levels to prevent frustration.
catFitness.toyCatnipSession: Present fresh catnip or catnip-infused toy. Response lasts 5–15 min. Allow 1–2 hour cooldown.
catFitness.toyCatnipSafety1: About 30–50% of cats do not respond to catnip (genetic).
catFitness.toyCatnipSafety3: Some cats become aggressive — discontinue if so.
catFitness.toyCatnipSafety4: Silver vine is an alternative for non-responders.
catFitness.toyClimbingSession: Encourage climbing by placing treats or toys at different levels.
catFitness.toyClimbingSafety1: Ensure tree is stable and secured — tip-over risk with large cats.
catFitness.toyClimbingSafety2: Not recommended for senior cats or cats with joint issues.
catFitness.toyClimbingSafety3: Overweight cats: ensure shelves support their weight.
catFitness.toyTreatScatterSession: Scatter a small number of treats (5–10) across a room or in a snuffle mat. 5–15 min.
catFitness.toyTreatScatterSafety1: Count scattered treats as part of daily caloric intake.
catFitness.toyTreatScatterSafety2: Use low-calorie treats for overweight cats.
catFitness.toyAutomatedSession: Use as supplement, not replacement for interactive play. Limit to 10–15 min.
catFitness.toyAutomatedSafety1: Supervise electronic toys — entanglement and battery risks.
catFitness.toyAutomatedSafety3: Not a substitute for interactive human-cat play.
